awd_titl_txt: DMREF/GOALI: Novel 3D Experiments, Simulations, and Optimization for Accelerated Design of Metallic Foams
awd_abstract_narration:
Open-cell metallic foams are an exciting class of structural materials that comprise a network of interconnected metallic ligaments, resulting in an interesting foam architecture. These low-density materials have garnered much attention over the past two decades based on their recognized potential for use in multi-functional applications. For example, in addition to serving as light-weight, load-bearing structures, open-cell metallic foams have the potential to serve concurrently as electrodes for energy-storage devices, as hosts for newly generated bone and blood vessels in biomedical implants, or as impact absorbers and noise insulators for advanced high-speed ground transportation. Despite their potential, the widespread deployment of open-cell metallic foams for a broader range of multi-functional applications remains hampered by inefficient, trial-and-error manufacturing approaches. This Designing Materials to Revolutionize and Engineer our Future (DMREF) Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award supports a joint academic-industry research effort to enable more efficient and intelligent design of open-cell metallic foams, and to achieve precise control over their performance for targeted applications. The results will provide dramatic improvements for the industry by increasing both the manufacturing efficiency and the tailorability of the foams, which will help to expand deployment of the foams throughout the energy, defense, biomedical, aerospace, and automotive industries. The research team will host outreach activities to expose students in K-12, undergraduate, and graduate school to this multi-disciplinary STEM research.

This DMREF GOALI award supports research to enable an accelerated and performance-based design paradigm for open-cell metallic foams through the integration of emergent methods in 3D materials characterization with multi-scale modeling and Bayesian optimization. The new design paradigm will be made possible through the discovery of process-structure-property relationships in the foams. The specific objectives include: experimentally modifying manufacturing parameters to produce variants of open-cell metallic foams; performing 3D synchrotron-based crystal-orientation measurements and in-situ X-ray computed tomography experiments to gain unprecedented insight into the hierarchical structure and multi-scale deformation mechanisms of the foam; using high-fidelity, multi-scale (grain-to-continuum) finite-element modeling to investigate micromechanical behavior and predict performance of the as-manufactured foams; conducting virtual tests on synthetic-foam variants to further populate a metallic-foam design space; and using Bayesian optimization on the simulation-based results to enable selection of optimal hierarchical structures (i.e. topology and crystallography) for targeted performance metrics. The research will be a first to decouple the effects of ligament topology and underlying crystal structure on micromechanical behavior of open-cell metallic foams (including microbuckling, local accumulation of slip, and distribution of crack-nucleation sites), which is postulated to influence its performance.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this NSF DMREF/GOALI project was to enable tailorable design of open-cell metal foams by discovering and exploiting process-structure-property relationships of the foams through close collaboration with an industry partner who manufactures them. To accomplish this, we performed tasks that included measuring and modeling an assortment of both real foam samples provided by our industry partner and virtual foams created using new software that we developed as part of this project. The primary outcomes in terms of intellectual merit and broader impacts are described below. This NSF-funded research resulted in at least 10 peer-reviewed publications and 20 conference presentations or invited seminars. Data generated from this research are publicly available at multiple locations, including the NIST Materials Data Repository, GitHub, and the Materials Commons hosted by the PRISMS Center.

Intellectual Merit

New software technology:

We developed two key software technologies that enable scientific discoveries into the relationships between the structure of open-cell metal foams and their mechanical performance. Both have been distributed publicly and are described in related journal publications.

  • The first is an "Establish Foam Morphology" filter for the software DREAM.3D. The filter allows for the generation of grain-mapped polycrystals for open-cell foams. Previously, DREAM.3D capabilities were limited to fully dense polycrystals. The new capability extends the utility of DREAM.3D and opens up new opportunities for materials simulation and analysis.  
  • The second is a foam-tracking software that enables quantification of ligament-scale attributes for large volumes of open-cell foams. To accomplish this, we introduced a new density measurement to identify nodal structures and techniques to track topological features over time. The quantification is performed in an automated fashion upon reading in image stacks from either numerical simulation or experimental measurements, and the time-tracking feature facilitates assessment of deformation and failure mechanisms at the ligament scale.

New insights:

We established key insights into the relationship between material structure and mechanical response of open-cell metal foams, which were enabled by integrating the aforementioned software into new experimental and numerical workflows. Experimentally, we performed first-of-a-kind measurements of foam under compressive loading while tracking the deformed ligament shapes and crystal orientations using a combination of in-situ tomography and high-energy X-ray diffraction microscopy (HEDM). We also collected statistics on ligament attributes for 58 foam samples produced under variable manufacturing parameters. Numerically, we performed the first known simulations of 3D open-cell foams by explicitly resolving ligaments and underlying grain structure. The following findings resulted from these efforts:

  • The plateau stress and energy absorption capacity of the foam exhibit Hall-Petch-like behavior for grain sizes below a certain threshold, above which the mechanical behavior of the bulk foam tends to saturate.
  • For a given grain structure, the plateau stress is greater in oxidized foam than in non-oxidized foam, owing to the strengthening effect of the oxidation layer, which serves as a barrier to dislocation motion.
  • The extent to which grain structure impacts the crushing behavior of open-cell foam depends on the surface conditions. The effect of grain size on mechanical response is more pronounced in the non-oxidized case than in the oxidized case, suggesting that the ratio of unconstrained free-surface area to grain-boundary area controls the range of variability in mechanical response of open-cell metallic foams.
  • By modifying the values of σy and C4 in the Gibson-Ashby model to account for grain size and surface condition, we demonstrated that the accuracy and generalizability of the Gibson-Ashby model can be significantly enhanced.

Our industry partner has been able to further innovate their material offerings as a result of the deeper understanding and tools developed through this project.

Broader Impacts

We launched an annual semester-long outreach program aimed at encouraging young students from underrepresented populations in STEM to pursue STEM fields by introducing them to both current and developing engineering technologies. A local middle school was selected for the program based on its large enrollment of students from racial minority groups. Graduate and undergraduate students from the University of Utah developed and taught lessons at the middle school each spring on subjects including 3D printing, computed tomography, and technical writing. The middle-school students worked in teams to develop persuasive proposals to image and print an object of their choosing. The proposals were peer-evaluated, and the students selected a winning object to be imaged and printed at the University of Utah. The annual program culminated with a field trip to the University of Utah campus in May for the middle-school students to learn about campus life and the College of Engineering and to see the 3D printing process in action as the winning object was revealed to them. Based on survey results, a majority of student participants reported that the program inspired an interest in engineering that they did not have prior to participating in the program.


Last Modified: 01/03/2022
Modified by: Ashley Spear

Images (1 of )
  • Schematic of the far-field HEDM setup at the Advanced Photon Source 1-ID beamline and the three relevant coordinate systems for tracking grains throughout applied displacement of open-cell foams: laboratory frame (xLab,yLab,zLab), ligament frame (x',y',z'), and crystal frame (a1,a2,a3).
    Ashley Spear
    Copyrighted
    Ashley Spear
    HEDM setup to map 3D grain structure
  • 3D grain maps generated from HEDM data collected at four displacement steps applied to open-cell aluminum foam. The crystal orientation of each grain is represented using standard IPF colors with the Z, or loading axis, being the reference direction.
    Quinton Johnson
    Copyrighted
    Ashley Spear
    3D grain maps from HEDM experiments
  • Process for generating grain-resolved open-cell foam models. (a) Synthetic fully dense polycrystal instantiated using DREAM.3D. (b) Foam mask from reconstruction of X-ray CT data. (c) Grain-resolved open-cell foam model generated by overlaying the foam mask with the polycrystalline domain.
    Zhao, et al. (2021) Materials Science and Engineering: A. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.msea.2021.140847
    Copyrighted
    Ashley Spear
    Foam with synthetic grain structure
  • Effective stress-strain responses of different grain-resolved, non-oxidized foam models. The average grain size is normalized by average geometric parameters of the struts to quantify the typical number of grains along the length (L/2a) and across the thickness (t/2c) of a nominal strut.
    Zhao, et al. (2021) Materials Science and Engineering: A. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.msea.2021.140847
    Copyrighted
    Ashley Spear
    Effect of grain size on crush response of open-cell foam (non-oxidized)
  • Comparison between plateau stress based on high-fidelity numerical simulations and the plastic collapse strength based on the Gibson-Ashby formula versus average grain size for non-oxidized open-cell aluminum 6101-T6 foam. The Gibson-Ashby formula is evaluated using three different approaches.
    Zhao, et al. (2021) Materials Science and Engineering: A. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.msea.2021.140847
    Copyrighted
    Ashley Spear
    Comparison of plastic collapse curves with Gibson-Ashby model
  • Visualization of ligament feature extraction performed for large volumes of open-cell foams. Features include ligament length, orientation, cross-sectional dimensions, and curvature.
    Attila Gyulassy, Steve Petruzza, Valerio Pascucci
    Copyrighted
    Ashley Spear
    High-throughput feature extraction for open-cell foam analysis
por.por_txt_cntn:
The overarching goal of this NSF DMREF/GOALI project was to enable tailorable design of open-cell metal foams by discovering and exploiting process-structure-property relationships of the foams through close collaboration with an industry partner who manufactures them. To accomplish this, we performed tasks that included measuring and modeling an assortment of both real foam samples provided by our industry partner and virtual foams created using new software that we developed as part of this project. The primary outcomes in terms of intellectual merit and broader impacts are described below. This NSF-funded research resulted in at least 10 peer-reviewed publications and 20 conference presentations or invited seminars. Data generated from this research are publicly available at multiple locations, including the NIST Materials Data Repository, GitHub, and the Materials Commons hosted by the PRISMS Center.

New software technology:

We developed two key software technologies that enable scientific discoveries into the relationships between the structure of open-cell metal foams and their mechanical performance. Both have been distributed publicly and are described in related journal publications.

The first is an "Establish Foam Morphology" filter for the software DREAM.3D. The filter allows for the generation of grain-mapped polycrystals for open-cell foams. Previously, DREAM.3D capabilities were limited to fully dense polycrystals. The new capability extends the utility of DREAM.3D and opens up new opportunities for materials simulation and analysis.

The plateau stress and energy absorption capacity of the foam exhibit Hall-Petch-like behavior for grain sizes below a certain threshold, above which the mechanical behavior of the bulk foam tends to saturate.
For a given grain structure, the plateau stress is greater in oxidized foam than in non-oxidized foam, owing to the strengthening effect of the oxidation layer, which serves as a barrier to dislocation motion.
The extent to which grain structure impacts the crushing behavior of open-cell foam depends on the surface conditions. The effect of grain size on mechanical response is more pronounced in the non-oxidized case than in the oxidized case, suggesting that the ratio of unconstrained free-surface area to grain-boundary area controls the range of variability in mechanical response of open-cell metallic foams.
By modifying the values of σy and C4 in the Gibson-Ashby model to account for grain size and surface condition, we demonstrated that the accuracy and generalizability of the Gibson-Ashby model can be significantly enhanced.


Our industry partner has been able to further innovate their material offerings as a result of the deeper understanding and tools developed through this project.

We launched an annual semester-long outreach program aimed at encouraging young students from underrepresented populations in STEM to pursue STEM fields by introducing them to both current and developing engineering technologies. A local middle school was selected for the program based on its large enrollment of students from racial minority groups. Graduate and undergraduate students from the University of Utah developed and taught lessons at the middle school each spring on subjects including 3D printing, computed tomography, and technical writing. The annual program culminated with a field trip to the University of Utah campus in May for the middle-school students to learn about campus life and the College of Engineering and to see the 3D printing process in action as the winning object was revealed to them. Based on survey results, a majority of student participants reported that the program inspired an interest in engineering that they did not have prior to participating in the program.
